blog.name: churro-parker
blog.title: it's always missing tony+nat hours
blog.description: || belle || bi || minor || Major Peter Parker Enthusiast || this blog is 97% marvel and 3% dc || i'll take requests! imagines, moodboards, headcanons, all that good stuff || no smut ||

body:
Oct. 12 - Marvel

October 12th - “Who could do this?”

Fanfiction

MCU

Warnings - One (1) swear word

Word Count - 468 (just a small one)

((In which Emma is also a teenage Avenger!))

____________________________________

The three teenagers sat before Mr. Stark. They were doing a training exercise; he would give them a scenario, and they would have to come up with a good, super-hero worthy solution.

“Alright,” said Mr. Stark. “A highly populated building is on fire-” Emma tried to jump in, but Mr. Stark continued, “-and… the is a zombie outbreak spreading like wildfire, pun intended. You don’t know if some of the people in the building are zombies, and there are confirmed zombies creeping, slowly, but surely, up to you from the street. What do you do?”

“Call the Avengers!” Emma shouted for the 15th time.

“For the last time, Em, we are the Avengers!” Shuri couldn’t help but smile as Peter and Emma giggled. “Okay, if the people in the building are zombies,” said Shuri, “they could bite us while we save them. Emma should go in,”

“Wha- why me?” Emma asked her friend. “Why can’t either of you two go in the burning zombie building? Peter’s got radioactive blood! Can he even be zombified?”

“He can,” Mr. Stark told her just before Peter opened his mouth in protest. “And Shuri’s right. Let her explain.”

Shuri nodded, smirking. “You’ve got super-speed. You can go in and come out fast enough to save everyone, and if there is a zombie, you can get away fast enough that you won’t get bitten.”

“Plus, don’t you have electricity in your blood?” Peter chimed in. “You have lightning IN YOUR HANDS! If anyone’s immune to a zombie bite, it’s you.”

“She’s not.”

“Gee, thanks guys.” Emma sighed. “Well, if I’m going into the building to get the civilians, what are you two doing?“

“Peter’s trying to put out the fire while I’m kicking zombie ass,” Shuri provided. “Sorry,” she added, with a nervous glance towards Mr. Stark.

“Is that your final answer?” Mr. Stark asked them. They all looked at each other for a second, then nodded. “Here’s what happens: Emma burns to a crisp, Shuri gets zombified, and Peter comes back crying because it’s all his fault.”

Peter blushed. “Why do I have to cry, though?”

“Don’t lie, you would.” Emma laughed, poking him in the ribs. “What happened this time?”

“First of all,” Mr. Stark began, earning a groan from all three kids. “Shuri got bitten because it was one against… maybe 40? Emma died because Peter’s first instinct was to go in the building for water, then he realized he couldn’t. So he ran around trying to get water, and by the time he had water, the building had already burned down, with her, and all the people in it. Then he cried.”

“Who could do this?” Emma cried, frustrated. “It’s sooo hard! Even when you have a good plan, something can always go wrong! It’s inevitable!”

“That’s where we come in.” Mr. Stark told her. “Don’t worry, you’ll get the hang of it.”

blog.name: strangemischief
blog.title: What Strange Trickery This Is
blog.description: Ironstrange + Supremefamily | Occasional Thor or Loki Content | Side Blog | Tag List | Ao3

body:
Im gonna cry

You know in infinity war when Tony is in the sanctum and he says “this is him” (maybe this it?) after Bruce says Thanos sent Loki.

Yeah well I rewatched AOU right before I rewatched Infinity War and realized he was talking about that vision Wanda gave him and how he could have saved them.

It was never about New York.

It was a foreshadow like Tony thought it was.

title: Tomorrow and Tomorrow
body:

by YellowDistress

(Continuation of ‘Stars, Hide Your Fires’)

blog.name: badbackgroundscience
blog.title: Bad Background Science
blog.description: Science. Superheroes. Supervillains. But not superpowers. Other people have already done that.

title: How does Iron Man smile?
body:
That’s not the set up of a joke I genuinely want to know ‘cause that mask is not particularly deformable.

We last left Iron Man in the clutches of the Mandarin (or at least I did - I didn’t explicitly state he had been captured in the blog post). But he escapes almost immediately, then sets off to complete his plan (I also never mentioned) of getting Tony Stark’s missiles back to the States.

See, the Mandarin’s got this special ‘ray’ he uses to steal missiles the US is attempting to bomb him with, and just stores them for a rainy day. Our military, meanwhile, stupidly - but totally in line with what you’d expect - keeps firing even more at him.

Luckily, Tony manages to keep the latest missile from getting captured by kicking it.

We never hear about this missile ever again, strangely. Surely it should have made a very large boom nearby. But we’re not privy to that information.

However, Tony imparting a force to the missile in order to change its trajectory could hypothetically move it out of the way of the Mandarin’s ray. The amount of force he’d need depends on the missile’s velocity and mass (or its momentum, which is calculated by multiplying those two things together), and also Tony’s velocity and mass, but this is ‘basic’ collision physics stuff.*

Sending this latest rocket off to Odin knows where, Tony returns to the Mandarin’s lair to destroy his missile-stealing hardware. With a rock.

Now, “nitro-fission”…

Taken separately, “nitro” and “fission” are real science things. The prefix nitro- refers to the element nitrogen, number 7 on the periodic table (between carbon and oxygen). Compounds that start with it - e.g. nitroglycerine, nitrocellulose, nitrous oxide - all contain some amount of nitrogen and also tend to be good at exploding to some degree.** Explosions are chemical reactions that, as you well know, release a lot of energy.

Fission reactions also release a lot of energy…sometimes. Nuclear fission involves a single atom of some element (You’re most familiar with Uranium and Plutonium) breaking apart into 2ish daughter elements and some spare neutrons. Pound-for-pound, or rather gram-for-gram (since we care about mass, not the effects of Earth’s mass on that mass), nuclear reactions are waaay more energetic than chemical reactions, because the force that holds nuclei together is waaay stronger than the force that holds multiple atoms together.

But let’s return to that “sometimes” - energy is only released if the total amount of energy required to induce fission is less than what is produced. Theoretically, any atom that isn’t Hydrogen-1 can be forced to undergo fission, but for energy-creating needs, it’s only worth it to do it with elements heavier than iron.

The graph above charts what’s called the Nuclear Binding Energy - the amount of energy stored up in the bonds between the protons and neutrons in an atom’s nucleus. For the first portion of the graph (i.e. up to iron), energy is released through the process of nuclear fusion - i.e. forming a more massive atom from smaller ones.

As element number 7, Nitrogen is solidly on the “fusion” part of this chart. You can force it to undergo fission, but you won’t get as much energy out as you have to put in.

Which would make it a terrible fuel source for powering anything, let alone a giant missile-stealing machine.


* (Assuming the missile doesn’t have a self-correcting guidance system of some sort, like a pigeon inside it.)

** Nitrous oxide is both laughing gas and the stuff you inject into car engines to win drag races.

Tales of Suspense #55 - Writer: Stan Lee, Art: Don Heck

NBE chart, Public Domain

Now, “nitro-fission”…

Taken separately, “nitro” and “fission” are real science things. The prefix nitro- refers to the element nitrogen, number 7 on the periodic table (between carbon and oxygen). Compounds that start with it - e.g. nitroglycerine, nitrocellulose, nitrous oxide - all contain some amount of nitrogen and also tend to be good at exploding to some degree.** Explosions are chemical reactions that, as you well know, release a lot of energy.

Fission reactions also release a lot of energy…sometimes. Nuclear fission involves a single atom of some element (You’re most familiar with Uranium and Plutonium) breaking apart into 2ish daughter elements and some spare neutrons. Pound-for-pound, or rather gram-for-gram (since we care about mass, not the effects of Earth’s mass on that mass), nuclear reactions are waaay more energetic than chemical reactions, because the force that holds nuclei together is waaay stronger than the force that holds multiple atoms together.

But let’s return to that “sometimes” - energy is only released if the total amount of energy required to induce fission is less than what is produced. Theoretically, any atom that isn’t Hydrogen-1 can be forced to undergo fission, but for energy-creating needs, it’s only worth it to do it with elements heavier than iron.

The graph above charts what’s called the Nuclear Binding Energy - the amount of energy stored up in the bonds between the protons and neutrons in an atom’s nucleus. For the first portion of the graph (i.e. up to iron), energy is released through the process of nuclear fusion - i.e. forming a more massive atom from smaller ones.

As element number 7, Nitrogen is solidly on the “fusion” part of this chart. You can force it to undergo fission, but you won’t get as much energy out as you have to put in.

Which would make it a terrible fuel source for powering anything, let alone a giant missile-stealing machine.


* (Assuming the missile doesn’t have a self-correcting guidance system of some sort, like a pigeon inside it.)

** Nitrous oxide is both laughing gas and the stuff you inject into car engines to win drag races.

[[MORE]]

Tales of Suspense #55 - Writer: Stan Lee, Art: Don Heck

NBE chart, Public Domain
trail.content:
That’s not the set up of a joke I genuinely want to know ‘cause that mask is not particularly deformable.

We last left Iron Man in the clutches of the Mandarin (or at least I did - I didn’t explicitly state he had been captured in the blog post). But he escapes almost immediately, then sets off to complete his plan (I also never mentioned) of getting Tony Stark’s missiles back to the States.

See, the Mandarin’s got this special ‘ray’ he uses to steal missiles the US is attempting to bomb him with, and just stores them for a rainy day. Our military, meanwhile, stupidly - but totally in line with what you’d expect - keeps firing even more at him.

Luckily, Tony manages to keep the latest missile from getting captured by kicking it.

We never hear about this missile ever again, strangely. Surely it should have made a very large boom nearby. But we’re not privy to that information.

However, Tony imparting a force to the missile in order to change its trajectory could hypothetically move it out of the way of the Mandarin’s ray. The amount of force he’d need depends on the missile’s velocity and mass (or its momentum, which is calculated by multiplying those two things together), and also Tony’s velocity and mass, but this is ‘basic’ collision physics stuff.*

Sending this latest rocket off to Odin knows where, Tony returns to the Mandarin’s lair to destroy his missile-stealing hardware. With a rock.

Now, “nitro-fission”…

Taken separately, “nitro” and “fission” are real science things. The prefix nitro- refers to the element nitrogen, number 7 on the periodic table (between carbon and oxygen). Compounds that start with it - e.g. nitroglycerine, nitrocellulose, nitrous oxide - all contain some amount of nitrogen and also tend to be good at exploding to some degree.** Explosions are chemical reactions that, as you well know, release a lot of energy.

Fission reactions also release a lot of energy…sometimes. Nuclear fission involves a single atom of some element (You’re most familiar with Uranium and Plutonium) breaking apart into 2ish daughter elements and some spare neutrons. Pound-for-pound, or rather gram-for-gram (since we care about mass, not the effects of Earth’s mass on that mass), nuclear reactions are waaay more energetic than chemical reactions, because the force that holds nuclei together is waaay stronger than the force that holds multiple atoms together.

But let’s return to that “sometimes” - energy is only released if the total amount of energy required to induce fission is less than what is produced. Theoretically, any atom that isn’t Hydrogen-1 can be forced to undergo fission, but for energy-creating needs, it’s only worth it to do it with elements heavier than iron.

The graph above charts what’s called the Nuclear Binding Energy - the amount of energy stored up in the bonds between the protons and neutrons in an atom’s nucleus. For the first portion of the graph (i.e. up to iron), energy is released through the process of nuclear fusion - i.e. forming a more massive atom from smaller ones.

As element number 7, Nitrogen is solidly on the “fusion” part of this chart. You can force it to undergo fission, but you won’t get as much energy out as you have to put in.

Which would make it a terrible fuel source for powering anything, let alone a giant missile-stealing machine.


* (Assuming the missile doesn’t have a self-correcting guidance system of some sort, like a pigeon inside it.)

** Nitrous oxide is both laughing gas and the stuff you inject into car engines to win drag races.

Tales of Suspense #55 - Writer: Stan Lee, Art: Don Heck

NBE chart, Public Domain
trail.content_abstract:
That’s not the set up of a joke I genuinely want to know ‘cause that mask is not particularly deformable.

We last left Iron Man in the clutches of the Mandarin (or at least I did - I didn’t explicitly state he had been captured in the blog post). But he escapes almost immediately, then sets off to complete his plan (I also never mentioned) of getting Tony Stark’s missiles back to the States.

See, the Mandarin’s got this special ‘ray’ he uses to steal missiles the US is attempting to bomb him with, and just stores them for a rainy day. Our military, meanwhile, stupidly - but totally in line with what you’d expect - keeps firing even more at him.

Luckily, Tony manages to keep the latest missile from getting captured by kicking it.

We never hear about this missile ever again, strangely. Surely it should have made a very large boom nearby. But we’re not privy to that information.

However, Tony imparting a force to the missile in order to change its trajectory could hypothetically move it out of the way of the Mandarin’s ray. The amount of force he’d need depends on the missile’s velocity and mass (or its momentum, which is calculated by multiplying those two things together), and also Tony’s velocity and mass, but this is ‘basic’ collision physics stuff.*

Compounds that start with it - e.g. nitroglycerine, nitrocellulose, nitrous oxide - all contain some amount of nitrogen and also tend to be good at exploding to some degree.** Explosions are chemical reactions that, as you well know, release a lot of energy.

Fission reactions also release a lot of energy…sometimes. Nuclear fission involves a single atom of some element (You’re most familiar with Uranium and Plutonium) breaking apart into 2ish daughter elements and some spare neutrons. But let’s return to that “sometimes” - energy is only released if the total amount of energy required to induce fission is less than what is produced. Theoretically, any atom that isn’t Hydrogen-1 can be forced to undergo fission, but for energy-creating needs, it’s only worth it to do it with elements heavier than iron.

The graph above charts what’s called the Nuclear Binding Energy - the amount of energy stored up in the bonds between the protons and neutrons in an atom’s nucleus. For the first portion of the graph (i.e. up to iron), energy is released through the process of nuclear fusion - i.e. forming a more massive atom from smaller ones.

As element number 7, Nitrogen is solidly on the “fusion” part of this chart. You can force it to undergo fission, but you won’t get as much energy out as you have to put in.

Which would make it a terrible fuel source for powering anything, let alone a giant missile-stealing machine.


* (Assuming the missile doesn’t have a self-correcting guidance system of some sort, like a pigeon inside it.)

** Nitrous oxide is both laughing gas and the stuff you inject into car engines to win drag races.

blog.description: This blog is an automated list of the stories posted on Archive Of Our Own under the Tony Stark tag. The stories are automatically posted here from the AO3 RSS feed.

title: Insight
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2pSHZXJ

by AliceN_Wolf

What was supposed to be an innocent look into the future for her friends well-being, Casey Madison saw so much more. A life lived in the Avengers Tower, a war… the world turning to dust… the love of her life gone. She has to warn Tony without putting the pressure to save everyone on his shoulders and the results of her first vision will come to light.

Can Casey help Tony make the right decisions to keep the universe from the path of destruction?

Words: 3719, Chapters: 1/?, Language: English

  • Fandoms: Marvel Cinematic Universe, The Avengers (Marvel) - All Media Types, Spider-Man: Homecoming (2017)
  • Rating: Teen And Up Audiences
  • Warnings: Graphic Depictions Of Violence, Major Character Death
  • Categories: F/M
  • Characters: Original Female Character(s), Peter Parker, Tony Stark, Pepper Potts, Aunt May, Avengers Team (MCU), Happy (MCU), Ned Leeds, Michelle Jones
  • Relationships: Peter Parker/Original Female Character(s), Pepper Potts/Tony Stark
  • Additional Tags: Clairvoyance, Telepathy, Precious Peter Parker, Parent Tony Stark, Parent Pepper Potts, Tony Stark Has A Heart


read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2pSHZXJ

blog.name: taryn-not-fromstarwars
blog.title: Taryn C
blog.description: I just post random Star Wars and Marvel stuff that comes to mind when I watch the movies.

summary: Watching Spider-Man: Homecoming again, and who all was Tony talking about when he said, “everyone else thought I was crazy to...
body: Watching Spider-Man: Homecoming again, and who all was Tony talking about when he said, “everyone else thought I was crazy to recruit a 14 year old kid.” Like who all on Team Iron Man knew Spider-Man was a literal child.

reblog.comment: Watching Spider-Man: Homecoming again, and who all was Tony talking about when he said, “everyone else thought I was crazy to recruit a 14 year old kid.” Like who all on Team Iron Man knew Spider-Man was a literal child.

title: Steve's hope
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2pUrTNb

by overlysarcasticmortal

Steve is having a hard time in the 21st century and nobody notices it. When he decides he’s had enough, a spider comes along to help him.

Promise me this. If I lose to myself. You won’t mourn a day. And you’ll move on to someone else- Twenty One Pilots.

(summary sucks. Please read.)
WARNING: SUICIDE ATTEMPTS.
